Circuit-switched is faster than packet-switched network

Error detection uses the concept of redundancy, which means adding extra bits for detecting errors at the destination
Error detection means to decide whether the received data is correct or not without having a copy of the original message

What is a data link collision?

Answers.Text: When all of the nodes receive multiple frames at the same time; that is, the transmitted frames collide at all of the receivers.
When a node buffer gets full
Because all nodes are capable of transmitting frames, two or more simultaneous transmissions (two or more signals at same time) cause interference.

When a node buffer gets full

Questions.Question: Which of the following apply to "burst errors" (select all that apply)?

Answers.Text: The term burst error means that two or more bits in the data unit have changed
Burst error means all the data is corrupted
Burst errors do not necessarily mean that the errors occur in consecutive bits
Burst errors are where the wrong data is sent
A host received a corrupted information

Questions.Question: How can the length of a burst error be measured?

Answers.Text: Burst error is measured by dividing the packet size by the packet header
The length of the burtst error is equal to header size
The length of the burst error is the size of the packet without header
The length of the burst is measured from the first corrupted bit to the last corrupted bit

Answers.Text: Gives hardware addresses to all interfaces
Defines how packets are placed on the media

Questions.Question: Which is true of the Physical Layer?

Answers.Text: Properties such as voltage, wire speed and connector pin-outs are defined at this layer

Questions.Question: Which of the following LAN topologies requires the most cabling?

Unlike a hub, which blindly forwards received bits, a bridge makes intelligent forwarding decisions based on the destination MAC address present in a frame.

Topics.Topic: Sliding Window Protocol and Network Collisions

Questions.Question: Explain how the sliding window protocol handles data transfer when a frame is corrupted.

Answers.Text: The sender sets a timeout for each frame sent. If a frame is missed, the receiver sends acknowledgments for the received frames and ignores the rest. The sender resends the missed frames after the timeout.
The sender stops sending any frames and waits for the receiver to request the missed frames.
The receiver automatically requests the missed frames without waiting for the sender's timeout.
The sender continues sending new frames without resending the missed frames.

Questions.Question: What is a collision in data communication and networking?

Answers.Text: A collision occurs when two or more nodes transmit frames simultaneously, causing interference.
A collision occurs when a node fails to transmit a frame due to a network error.
A collision occurs when a node receives multiple acknowledgments for the same frame.
A collision occurs when a node transmits a frame to an incorrect destination.

Questions.Question: How do nodes discover a collision in Ethernet and Wi-Fi?

Answers.Text: Ethernet uses CSMA/CD to detect collisions after they occur, while Wi-Fi uses CSMA/CA to avoid collisions before they happen.
Ethernet and Wi-Fi both use CSMA/CD to detect collisions after they occur.
Ethernet uses CSMA/CA to avoid collisions before they happen, while Wi-Fi uses CSMA/CD to detect collisions after they occur.
Ethernet and Wi-Fi both use CSMA/CA to avoid collisions before they happen.

Questions.Question: Explain TDM and FDM in a circuit-switched network.

Answers.Text: TDM divides time into frames and assigns time slots to connections, while FDM divides the frequency spectrum and assigns frequency bands to connections.
TDM divides the frequency spectrum and assigns frequency bands to connections, while FDM divides time into frames and assigns time slots to connections.
Both TDM and FDM divide the frequency spectrum and assign frequency bands to connections.
Both TDM and FDM divide time into frames and assign time slots to connections.

Questions.Question: What advantage does a circuit-switched network have over a packet-switched network?

Answers.Text: A circuit-switched network can guarantee a certain amount of end-to-end bandwidth for the duration of a call.
A circuit-switched network is more efficient in handling bursty data traffic.
A circuit-switched network has lower latency compared to a packet-switched network.
A circuit-switched network is more scalable than a packet-switched network.

Questions.Question: Using CRC error detection, determine if the frame 11011011011 is correct or corrupted. The generator G(x) is 10101.
What are the basic concepts of networks?

Answers.Text: Networks must be able to transfer data from one device to another with complete accuracy.
Networks must be able to transfer data from one device to another without any errors.

Questions.Question: Where are error detection and correction implemented in the OSI model?

Answers.Text: At the data link layer or the transport layer.
At the network layer or the application layer.

Questions.Question: If data is sent at a rate of 1Kbps and exposed to noise for 0.005 seconds, how many bits can be affected?
What is the throughput for a file transfer if the path has three links with rates R1 = 800 kbps, R2 = 2 Mbps, and R3 = 1.7 Mbps?
What is a collision at the data link layer?

Answers.Text: A collision happens when frames overlap over the network medium.
A collision happens when frames are lost in the network.

Questions.Question: Does the star topology require a hub at the center?

Answers.Text: No, it can also use a switch.
Yes, it must have a hub.

Questions.Question: What are the roles of the 'SYN' and 'ACK' flags during TCP connection establishment?

Answers.Text: SYN is used to synchronize counters, and ACK is used to acknowledge the receipt of a packet.
SYN is used to terminate a connection, and ACK is used to establish a connection.

Questions.Question: Which mode, TDMA or FDMA, is more suitable if 3 nodes share the same communication medium of 150kbps and each node is continuously sending 50Kbps?
What is the fundamental difference between a router and a link-layer switch?

Answers.Text: A router forwards a packet based on the packet’s IP address, while a link-layer switch forwards a packet based on the packet’s MAC address.
A router forwards a packet based on the packet’s MAC address, while a link-layer switch forwards a packet based on the packet’s IP address.

Questions.Question: Explain how the credit-based approach is used for TCP flow control.

Answers.Text: A requests B's permission to send a certain amount of data (credit). B grants a portion of the requested credit, and A starts sending messages. B acknowledges received messages and updates A's credit.
A sends data without requesting permission, and B acknowledges the data after receiving it.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer encapsulate network layer data into frames?

Answers.Text: The data link layer receives packets from the network layer and encapsulates them into frames by adding headers and trailers that contain control information.
The data link layer compresses the data and sends it directly to the physical layer.

Questions.Question: What methods are used to add headers and trailers to frames, and what information do they typically contain?

Answers.Text: Headers are added at the beginning of frames to include source and destination MAC addresses, while trailers may contain error-checking information such as CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check).
Headers and trailers are added randomly and contain no specific information.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer determine the size of a frame, and what considerations are involved in this process?

Answers.Text: Frame size is determined based on the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of the underlying network, taking into account the need for sufficient header and trailer space while avoiding fragmentation.
Frame size is always fixed and does not consider the MTU.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer control access to shared communication channels?

Answers.Text: The data link layer employs Medium Access Control (MAC) protocols, such as CSMA/CD or CSMA/CA, to manage access to shared channels and avoid collisions.
The data link layer allows all nodes to transmit simultaneously without any control.

Questions.Question: What role do MAC addresses play in identifying source and destination nodes in the headers of frames?

Answers.Text: MAC addresses uniquely identify network devices on the same local area network (LAN) and are used in frame headers to ensure that data is sent to the correct destination.
MAC addresses are used to identify the type of data being transmitted.

Questions.Question: Can you explain how the link layer resolves contention when multiple nodes attempt to access the channel simultaneously?

Answers.Text: Contention is resolved using MAC protocols that dictate rules for channel access, such as waiting for a random backoff time before attempting to transmit again.
Contention is resolved by allowing the strongest signal to dominate.

Questions.Question: What mechanisms are in place to ensure reliable delivery between adjacent nodes, especially over wireless links with high error rates?

Answers.Text: Mechanisms such as acknowledgment (ACK) frames and retransmission requests are used to confirm successful frame delivery and ensure reliability.
No mechanisms are in place; reliability is not a concern at the data link layer.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer detect when a frame has not been received correctly?

Answers.Text: The data link layer uses error detection techniques like checksums or CRC to determine if a received frame is corrupted.
The data link layer assumes all frames are received correctly without any checks.

Questions.Question: What strategies does the data link layer use to manage retransmissions?

Answers.Text: Upon detecting an error, the receiving station sends a negative acknowledgment (NAK) back to the sender, prompting it to retransmit the affected frame.
The data link layer does not manage retransmissions; it relies on the network layer.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer implement flow control to prevent data congestion?

Answers.Text: Flow control is implemented using mechanisms such as stop-and-wait, sliding window protocols, or credit-based systems to regulate the amount of data sent before needing an acknowledgment.
Flow control is not implemented at the data link layer.

Questions.Question: What techniques are used to ensure that slow receivers are not overwhelmed by fast senders?

Answers.Text: Techniques such as sliding windows and feedback mechanisms allow the sender to adjust the transmission rate based on the receiver's processing capability.
The data link layer does not consider the speed of the receiver.

Questions.Question: How are buffer sizes and flow control windows determined and managed at the data link layer?

Answers.Text: Buffer sizes and flow control windows are typically configured based on the expected network conditions and the capabilities of the devices involved, with dynamic adjustments possible.
Buffer sizes and flow control windows are fixed and cannot be adjusted.

Questions.Question: What hardware mechanisms are employed by the data link layer for error detection?

Answers.Text: Hardware mechanisms like checksums and CRC circuits are utilized to perform error detection on received frames at the data link layer.
Error detection is performed entirely by software at the network layer.

Questions.Question: How does the data link layer identify transmission errors caused by issues such as signal attenuation and noise?

Answers.Text: The data link layer analyzes the received frame against the computed error-checking information to identify discrepancies that indicate transmission errors.
The data link layer does not identify transmission errors; it relies on the physical layer.

Questions.Question: What actions does the receiver take when an error is detected in a received frame?

Answers.Text: When an error is detected, the receiver may request a retransmission of the corrupted frame or simply drop it, depending on the protocol in use.
The receiver ignores the error and processes the frame as if it were correct.

Questions.Question: What methods are used for error correction in the data link layer?

Answers.Text: Error correction can involve techniques like Forward Error Correction (FEC), where the sender includes redundant data, allowing the receiver to correct certain errors without needing retransmission.
Error correction is not performed at the data link layer.

Questions.Question: How does the receiver correct errors without requiring retransmission of the entire frame?

Answers.Text: The receiver uses the redundant data included in the original frame to identify and correct specific bit errors, allowing it to recover the original data without needing to ask for a resend.
The receiver cannot correct errors without retransmission.

Questions.Question: What are the advantages and limitations of error correction compared to error detection and retransmission?

Answers.Text: Error correction can improve efficiency by reducing the need for retransmissions, but it may introduce additional overhead due to the redundancy required and is limited in its ability to correct multiple errors.
Error correction has no advantages over error detection and retransmission.
